Comment: Still the most popular opening move.
Probably the best reply even now.
The best play, forever neutralizing the threat of ...Q-R5 ch.
An unusual, and somewhat conservative, variant.
Seizing command of the center, as is always White's objective in this opening.
Adding support to the advanced KBP, but because of Black's 3rd move, the supporting Pawn itself is now vulnerable.
White equalizes the material and aims his Knight at the weakened Black K-side.
Repositioning, with a discovered attack as well.
Rather than retreat, White adds support to the Knight.
Completing the fianchetto, attacking White's central Pawns, and preparing to castle.
Aiming at the usual target: the weak point at Black's KB2.
Tucking the King in what Black thinks is the safest available spot, while adding a guard to the KBP.
The alternative is 8... R-K1, which allows 9 BxP ch winning the Exchange. However, this move allows a quick checkmate!

Threatens 10 Q-R7 mate. If Black creates a flight square with 9... R-K1, 10 BxP ch gives Black the choice of 10... K-R1 11 Q-R7 mate or 10 K-B1 11 N-R7 ch with mate or overwhelming material gain for White to follow shortly.
Renewing the mate threat on KR7. Black resigns [10... R-K1 11 QxP mate.]
